File:Pendulum clock and two stems of roses
Sunday June 29
Hi Jack-Gladys.
It is 9 A.M. I overslept.  John had been up for some time looking over  his Gardens.  He woke me at 8.  We have had breakfast but we were talking of  you and old times.  So I remembered  your Anniversary will be Monday.  Wanted a [sic] excuse to write to you anyway.  Jack, when you were speaking of "The Old Horner house"
Completed

2
it rang a bell  in my brain but I couldn't place the house I kept thinging [sic] of the big old yellow house that burned by the track early one morning, remember?  Now I get it.  the perkins family lived there.  Ethel, Eula, Chester and Marvin.  I have spent many a good time there Spent Nights when old Grandma Fagle was living with the Perkins Family.  It had been at one time a very nice place but do you recall  how the floor to that great big living room would seem to dip and sway like a ship at sea.  it must have been larger that [sic] the whole of our 4 front rooms together.  Marvin Perkins just died about a month ago. or did you know?  died of a heart atack [sic] as Chester and Mrs Perkins both did.  So that lot out in Sugar Creek is the Ones who ?owned? the "Old Honer house"  Another thing Jack you remember Isobell told  you Joe Meads Wife teachs [sic] the Sugar Creek school?
Completed

4.  underlined  THE WIFE OF THE BOOK EDITOR 

  IT WAS THE SUMMER OF 1947.  The campaign was on to convince   Henry Wallace to run for President of the U.S.A. on a 3rd party ticket --and  to roll up a respectable vote for him if he decided to run.  (which, as you know, he did in 1948 as the Progressive Party candidate). 
   Writers and Artists for Wallace was formed to get writers and artists -- creative and performing -- on the bandwagon.   Mother ? and I were among the organizers.
   A public rally was held somewhere, near North or in the Loop.  (I don't remember where).   Conroy, who was then working for the Encyclopedia Brittanica, if I remember correctly, and Nelson Algren were among the speakers.  Musta been 300-500 in the audience.  Nothing spectacular, but a good rally.  The most memorable thing, for me, was Algren's answer to this question from the floor during the question-and-answer period:
   "Mr. Algren:  Why are you crossed out:  advocating support asking us to vote for a candidate who can't possibly win?  Isn't that throwing your vote away?"
   "I'd rather vote for somebody I want and not get him than vote for somebody I don't want and get him.  That's the only way I know not to throw my vote away."

It brought the house down.

    After the rally, a group of  us --10 as I remember it -- walked to the LaSalle Cafeteria on West Madison St at or near Clinton, across from the Northwestern train station
Completed

for coffee and and [sic] talk.

   As best as I can remember, the seating arrangement was like this:

SKETCH indicating 12 chairs around a table labeled as follows:  Paul Romaine, Marguarite Romaine  Mr Rosen   Roslyn Rosen   Jack Conroy   Studs Terkel
Ida Terkel   ?    Ken McCormick   Mrs. McCormick  Mike Hecht    Terry Hecht
Ken McCormick was (and is) senior editor/vice president Doubleday Books.
Roslyn Rosen now has Lund aded to her name, and 2 years ago her novel was very well received by critics and the public.
Paul Romaine:  Chicago literary figure and bookseller.

   Conroy was in jovial good form, and for half an hour, forty-five minutes, entertained us with stories and reminiscences.
   Just before McCormick called for the bill, Conroy told this one:
   "It was 1936 and the American Writers Against War and Fascism were having a Congress in New York.  There were a lot of fiery speeches and then as one of the afternoon sessions closed, James Farrell jumped up and shouted:  'Let's everybody go out and bomb the Chase Manhattan Bank!"
    While most of us were doubling up with laughter at this, Mrs. McCormick leaned over to her husband and whispered:  "Who's James Farrell?"
     Ah, to be the wife of a book editor!
Completed

greeting card  Peace, Joy and Happiness Throughout the Year
211 East 70th Street, Apt 31B
New York, N.Y.  10021
Dear Jack,

     Another year swallowed up by time.  There were major changes during the past one - we moved to a new apartment, I took up photography, and I parted ways with Harper - they finally turned down my last novel after all the work - and am looking for a new publisher.  Things being what they are in the trade, it is rough going.  But nothing ventured, nothing gained.  There are already copious notes for a new novel, still I am holding off.  The older one gets, the more of an emotional strain writing becomes.  Let's see how long I can stay off the wagon.
    I hope you're well and your old cheerful self.  Keep punching and have a good year!

Fondly,  ?Ybella?
Completed

1/2/76
Dear Jack & Gladys,

    I'm so sorry to hear the sad news about Margaret-Jean.   Under the circumstances, there are no words of consolation that anyone can offer.   All I can say, is I hope she isn't suffering too much.
    Congratulations on your honorary degree and I hope it becomes more useful in the near future.  Let me know when your collected works are finally published.  I'll want to buy a copy.
    Well, we have finally gotten to San Diego.  Our address is:
     4823 68th St., #38    San Diego, Calif.  92115
    We moved into our apartment on Dec. 18 and worked until we were ready to drop for about a week.  God, why does one accumulate so much junk.  And why is every piece so wrapped in sentiment that you can't bring yourself to part with and so pay to
Completed

2
have it transported and after paying for it, wind up by throwing away.   I'll bet I could have saved quite a bit of money if I had been a little bit more ruthless.  Oh  well.

  We have a lovely apartment in a building where they only rent to mature couples which means mostly retired people.  The building is built around a court which contains a swimming pool, a sauna and jacuzi (whirlpool) none of which I've had time for up until now.
   Our neighbors are all friendly and make you feel welcome.  I suppose because they are also transplanted.   Most of them are from the Midwest, so we feel very comfortable with them.
   The weather has been simply gorgeous.  Today is a cold day, 56º.  The sun has been out every day and the temperature has been between 65 and 75 degrees.
   Isadore joins me in  wishes you all the best.

As ever ?Fan?
You   told me once that you have some friends living here and to let you know when we move so we could get in touch with them.
Completed

Thief River Falls, Mn.
Jan. 5,   1976
Dear Friends,

      Didn't wish to spoil your Christmas season and consequently held off sending this devastating news.  If it hadn't been for my daughter and husband (and 4 kiddies) who took in this bruised and battered widow I don't know how I'd have survived all this.   Ben and I had a special kind of relationship.   When the surgeon's knife and cancer rendered  him impotent a few  months after our marriage we were really in low spirits.   The darling guy offered me my freedom since he couldn't truly be a husband!  But how underlined:  could I leave him, when he was already so shattered!
      I loved him until his last breath - and will never stop!   - was at the hospital those final 9 days when the cancer destroyed that marvelous brain and left him a babbling wreck.   Stood by his bed 12 hours while he was in his agony - how he fought to live!  Not until I hit on the idea of assuring him that I would be by his
Completed

side always, would never leave him, but that he must now surrender, as I was giving him back to God, did he relax a little.   Strange that I could penetrate his consciousness when noone else could, and a miracle that he had 45 minutes midway in that 9-day period when he was coherent and we could talk about necessary things.  Except for rasping "my darlings" at intermittent periods, his last words were to assure me that the best thing that ever happened to  him was when I married him, he couldn't get his thoughts together no matter how valiantly he struggled or how utterly frustrated he felt.  He couldn't swallow worth a darn after we returned from Rochester Nov. 21 and his mind became a wandering unable to do his bidding.  But I am thankful he could still relax under sedatives and that he didn't go beyond the point where medication couldn't relieve his pain.

   Jack, there are a lot of things he worried about in his diary - he said I could and should read it if he died.   He (and rightly so) didn't want such things as Northern Light etc. to fall  into
Completed

3
unappreciative hands.   He wanted his correspondence with celebrities to go to the Minn. Historical Society; I guess the postage will really break me but I must make an effort.   Are there some things you could enumerate for me, things you would want and cherish, or perhaps place somewhere so they wouldn't be unread, and forgotten.
Later today,
Going over some of the Christmas mail (which I couldn't open before)  I just discovered that you too are bearing a lead cross - your own daughter is suffering from Ca.   Oh, how sad that makes me feel, I am weeping with you . . . May God grant her surcease from her pain, and you and Gladys the fortitude to bear the burden...

    Let's keep in touch, and please let me know very soon what to do about Ben's writings etc.

Sharing our sorrows,  Flora
Completed

Jack Conroy:

     Please, give the people of Moberly a chance to vote for you as Councilman.  We are fast losing the right to have a choice in anything.  As you know 4 p.m. Friday is the deadline for announcing and there has to be as many as four Candidates.  You might get a lot of ideas for a book or two, while a councilman.  There's plenty of dirt to be cleaned up, at least.  The fact that you are a writer, of some note, might help.

Memories do not rest
Strange how so many things
Can bring you back to me.
A wild trail, a rose, a tree
Stirs a [sic] old memory.
In the white despair of Winter.
Or in the heart of June -
I remember you, I may find you
even in a popular tune.
There may be summer birds
or perhaps when they have fled.
There may be rambling roses,
Or when they all are dead.
if I were wise I would forget,
if I were calm and wise -
But I am ever disturbed by recalling
Your dark and flashing eyes.

   --Estella Davis taylor.

I like this except I think the last two lines spoil it some way.   I would have ended it by "your sweet and gentle eyes"  For I think of Mama when I read it she loved the woods, the trips through the fields to Grandmas, wild roses, etc.
if old pip had never moved on the scene!

63 Aldbourne Rd
Shepherds Bush
London W12
May 27th 1968
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    With great pleasure and thanks I recieved [sic] your "Die Enterbten".  I have read it through and marked quite a few places for corrections.  Also I want to reread the "Disinherited" and compare both books as it seems to me that the German translation is shortened in parts.   From a very quick judgement the translation by Klaus Schultz is the better one.   Though he had to continue the style of Gerhard Zottcher who put his translation into Zerliner jargon that is not spoken all over the Eastern parts of the country.  
   I definately [sic] will write my friends and relatives about the book because it has many parallels to the 20 in Germany -
  With only those few words today may I thank you for thinking of me.  Later I will write more about it.  At present I have some work to finish for Harvard University.
  Kindest regard to you and Mrs. Conroy

H. Janca Waysblum
Completed

Dear Jack:  I hope this brief note may reach you before you leave for Paris, but it doesn't have much chance.   I did want to wish you and Gladys a pleasant journey.  Illness and over-work have prevented my writing sooner.

   It hasn't been lack of appreciation that has delayed my thanks for the volume from the English Poets series.  I have owned them all at one time or the other except that rare 2nd volume which I have particularly wanted because it contained the Cavalier poets whose work is hard to find.  I guess the fact that the Earl of Rochester is one of the poets in the volume has made people hang on to it more.  There are five volumes in the series instead of four.  Many thanks for sending the book.

1612 S 5th Ave., Maywood, Ia
Dear Jack,

   I trust you had a wonderful time while you were in Europe.  Germany is the county that I have spent the most time in abroad, except Turkey.  I have been in Italy when I was traveling to and fro from U.S. -Turkey and U.S. & Germany. 
   The Carlton edition should be interesting. and I would like to see what you have to offer.  I think your little book with Arna Bontemps should be timely, and I hope it sells like hot cakes.  The Migration of Negroes and hill folk from the south is still terrific and I would wonder if you have thought of dealing with southern "whites" in your revision?
   Speaking of your book "Making" the grade in American Lit. classes - I read it in a special honors course on Modern Novel at Central College, Fayette, back in 1941.
   When we get together I have some questions to ask you about your honest assessment of The Church. then and now. Aug 7, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,

      I'm sorry that it has taken me so long to reply to your graduation card, but this has been a busy summer for me.   I'm thoroughly enjoying my work with Sears although it keeps me running all the time!  One week I worked 54 hours (14 hours free gratis) but since then I've slowed down a little.  I haven't written anything lately except a 20 page paper on Flannery O'Connor which I whipped up in one day for Dr. Creed.  Needless to say, it got the C it deserved.  But I was already in my 4th month of full time work with Sears and studying was far from my mind.  I did manage to pull out that diploma, though.
      I'm moving in a couple of weeks to another apartment here in Birmingham. How long I will be here only Atlanta knows.  My new address will be 111 16th Place SW,  Apt  20-C Birmingham Alabama, 35211, only about a mile from the college.
